comments.commentBody: Obama has maintained strong personal ties with the fiery reverend thoughout his years in Chicago. The story saying other wise was a flat-out lie provn by any review of Obama's own words and the times he introduced, ''My preacher, Rev. Wright.'' The first group Obama burned, however, were the businessmen who gave him an income right after he lost that House race years ago.
So then, CJ, are you saying that Obama flip flopped?
Reverend Wright wasn't out there acting as a surrogate for Obama and you know it.
Judging a man by the company he keeps?  This was the very issue with the president's long association with Reverend Wright.

An incredibly strange, condescending, self-important rant. Why, and why are people recommending it? The writer hints at being American, "like so many other Americans", but the writing feels very foreign, and the focus on investigating US politicians as opposed to foreign ones seems to be a typical diversionary strategy practiced by a particular country.

The core problem is belief. And the conviction that belief can substitute for fact. And that one's belief is superior to another's belief. And that legislation can be based on this.

I have to agree with you that an awful lot of extreme conservatism is based on discomfort with anything not clear cut, rigidly defined. I really have to wonder what has happened to so many people who seem to live in some kind of fear of uncertainty. Since when has life ever been certain in any way? Which person plans their day at the beginning and that day turns out exactly as planned, with no interruptions or digressions or sudden, unexpected occurances? Where did this fear in people come from? Is it Fox and Limbaugh and the like, ranting constantly? Is this the result of diabolical corporate planning and vision over decades, to woo a populace by fear, driving them to grasp onto belief instead of relaxing into a world that will always include some undertainty?

What would happen if the fear-filled, belief-clinging populace could be assured that for the most part, things can be okay? Would we then again be able to have some dialogue?

The outrageous statements and lies made openly by many extreme right-wing people this election scares me most because they are losing their fear of the public censuring them. Is that because the public is so fear-filled now they'll buy any lies, any ugliness without question? Has belief snuffed out an inquiring mind?

Katha Pollitt once wrote an article on this topic, pointing out that this extremist view relegates women to the status of potting soil.  A woman's already existing life and circumstances have no relevance for these people; she only exists to be a vessel of reproduction.

The real problem, Gail, is the belief that life begins at conception, which begets the stance that the life and well being of the mother needs to be weighed against the well being of a clump of cells.

The real problem is that people who hold this belief who want to consider themselves reasonable people have two choices: Either to live with some cognitive dissonance, and accept that some perfectly nice and moral people don't share their belief, or to conclude that theirs Is the reasonable attitude, and anybody who disagrees is immoral and has the extreme stance.

The problem with the first approach is it can lead to questioning and doubt, and a feeling of unease that morality might not be as clear cut as we would like.
For some people, this idea is so scary that they cling to the second approach and refuse to accept that different views are acceptable.
Obama cut his ties with Wright. Romney has not cut his ties with Sununu.

DJOKOVIC, LANCE ITO BASS, IRENE, DEDE Dinah, HILTONS, JUAREZ, JUNIPERO, ALASTAIR, ALEX, LOMAN, CEDRIC, John ColTRANE and KITT. Does this seem like too many names? To me it does. STD, SYST, ONT, INTR and INTL didn't help things either. Any two or three of these would've been OK, but put them all together and it becomes UGH. Also, no fewer than eleven E's in the NW corner alone: not much variety there. Wheelhouse, schmeelhouse. Sorry Joon, I did not like this much. Twelve debuts are great, but at what cost?

What I liked: CILANTRO, LETSROCK, ICECASTLE, CODEX and ESTRANGED. My favorite entry: COR.

It's late, maybe I'll feel better about it tomorrow morning.

Have a great weekend, everyone.

I agree. This is why I was disturbed back in the Clinton era when Democrats began to use language such as “should be rare” and “a painful decision” when speaking about terminating pregnancies. It’s like belief, if it’s awful for some, well, I’m all for addressing their needs and in my experience, Planned Parenthood is very good at providing a wide range of services that meet the needs of all women. They also respect that when a woman says, “I want to terminate”, that that is what she means.

Then we gave in on the funding issue, once again respecting THEIR views and separating the funds, but that has not been good enough either and we are accused of fanciful bookkeeping for our efforts.

I have four children--mostly planned. I have not completed every pregnancy. I am not embarrassed about that and it was not at all difficult to decide or carry out. I honestly have thought for a long time that women need to learn to do the D&C procedure themselves--it seems to be the only way we will truly have power over our own bodies.
I agree with Janet; abortion is not a difficult or wrenching choice for all women. Nor should it be portrayed as such. There is no shame in not wanting to continue an unplanned pregnancy.
I wish I were as confident as you that Roe v. Wade would survive a Romney presidency and the ultr-conservatives he would appoint to the Supreme Court.

"If you believe life begins at conception, then that’s a life, and you should try to convince women not to terminate any pregnancy, no matter what the cause."

Which is why we are hearing these people invoke all kinds of new explanations - pseudo-scientific or scientific - for banning abortions completely, regardless of circumstance. The GOP has systematically tried to change the nature of science and theology in order to further their aim to institute religious beliefs as the law of the land. Laws changing the very nature of conception and when it happens have been passed. Who would have thought that a zygote is conceived a couple of weeks before a couple has sex? Since Roe vs. Wade can't be changed, they've decided to change nature in order to abolish it. Distinguishing between varying degrees of rape makes some rape more like consensual sex. How cute of them?

Neither religion, philosophy, or even science can tell us exactly when a fetus is a person, or which properties make it so. The Roe v. Wade decision is as good a settlement of the issue as we will have for quite some time. We are a nation of nations. The zealots among us have to go back to minding their beliefs and keeping them to themselves. We all need to push all the way back this November. While they will always have the choice to live their lives according to their beliefs, we must fight to retain the right to live ours, our way. There are no more compromises to be made. There are no more gray areas. This is it.

@TerryDarc

"anybody’s guess" is what's known as a figure of speech. It does NOT imply that Mr. Silver is guessing. "anybody’s guess" is the equivalent of:
* It's too close to call
* dead heat
* essentially a tie

FDR's Electoral College votes:  1932, 472; 1936, 523; 1940, 449; 1944, 432.  His 1936 re-election was the most lopsided landslide in the history of seriously contested U.S. Presidential elections.  None of his four Electoral College victories were close.  Wilson's EV's did plummet from 435 to 277 when he was re-elected.

In rare cases (2000) the popular vote can go to one candidate while the electoral vote will not (Bush had fewer votes than Gore, but won the electoral college 271-266 with one abstention). It depends on how close the popular vote is. If it's very close, then the candidate who wins the right combination of states will carry the day, and in that case "cherry picking" would be an excellent election strategy. Alas, Romney's famous Op Ed in this paper--

www.nytimes.com/2008/11/19/opinion/19romney.html

--may prove his undoing not only in Michigan but also in Ohio.

So much wrong here but just hitting the obvious ones:

1) Gallup published this story today, but it's not describing a phenomenon that happened today; this distribution of party ID has been baked in to all of the polls we've been seeing throughout the campaign.

2) Party ID is fluid and most reputable pollsters don't weight their polls by this metric - Nate talked about this on Sept. 29: "But party identification is not a hard-and-fast demographic characteristic like race, age or gender. Instead, it can change in reaction to news and political events from the party conventions to the Sept. 11 attacks. Since changes in public opinion are precisely what polls are trying to measure, it would defeat the purpose of conducting a survey if pollsters insisted that they knew what it was ahead of time."

3) Nate isn't a pollster; he analyzes polling results. Are you new here?

4) The point of the Gallup piece was in fact that the demographics of the race - except for party ID - look substantially like they did in 2008 and 2004. According to Gallup, "Thus, key elements of President Obama's electoral coalition, such as racial minorities, women, young adults, and postgraduates will likely turn out at rates similar to those in 2008."

Just saying it might be a little early to start putting that champagne on ice : - )
Do u understand the electoral college? If u did u would understand BHO is leading in the states that will give him an electoral college win which is how a president is elected
Damn, someone said "whistling past the graveyard" again. Chock up another 10 cents on mTurk for the paid posters :P

Do you understand how the electoral college works?
It is based on the vote state by state, not on a national summation.
Shocking. This is all so un Mitt like!
Et tu?

I'm an Ohioan and I have requested signs and found out from the office here as is the case around the country that the campaign isn't much interested in spending resources on yard signs. They found in 08 and other elections that this activity doesn't move the needed and wanted to spend the resources by knocking on new registrants and if voters doors to GOTV. They believe this was a better use of resources and funds. Therefore, the reason why you are seeing so few signs.

I'm not sure why evangelicals would have chose not to vote vote for McCain, but why would an evangelical vote for a Mormon over a Christian in this election if they were voting based on religious beliefs?
He will be tqken seriously,has been in the past and will be even more in the future.the man is a brilliant man
You are a troll
Go back to Fox or worse. This is a serious blog. You do not belong here.
How many different usernames have you created in the last 24 hours on this site?
Love your extended metaphor, as it is most appropriate for this fury at the end of the campaign, especially as a hurricane bears down on the East Coast. I feel just like you do!
Gosh, you really destroyed Nate's argument there with all those detailed criticisms of his model's statistical flaws.

I live in Ohio and everything I have seen and heard....the Obama team is focusing their GOTV early voting on new registrants and iffy voters who didn't participate in 08 or 10. Its a site to see the volunteers walking the streets and knocking doors.

You are, of course, wrong in every single one of your suppositions. Nate does not assume that the turnout will look like 2008.  Remember - he nailed the 2010 midterms to the House seat closer than anybody else.   Undecideds do not break for the challenger by a significant degree - they go roughly 60:40 for the challenger at most.  Probably more like 53-47 for Romney, which won't amount to much since there are so few of them.  And the "strut" is a sham designed to sustain a media illusion that Romney is "winning" when none of the polls - even GOP-leaning ones - give Romney an electoral victory. Wisconsin is absolutely critical for Romney because Ohio looks unbreakable. Without Ohio, Romney must peel off Wisconsin. That explains the Minneapolis ad buy, which includes western Wisconsin in its market.   And the "talk" of Obama pulling out of NC and FL is bogus. And the only PA presence is the far western edge, which reaches eastern OH.
